title: Poldhu
text:
Poldhu is a small area in south <a href="Cornwall">Cornwall</a>, <a href="England">England</a>, <a href="United%20Kingdom">UK</a>, situated on the <a href="The%20Lizard">Lizard Peninsula</a>; it comprises Poldhu Point and Poldhu Cove. Poldhu means "black pool" in <a href="cornish%20language">Cornish</a>. Poldhu lies on the coast of <a href="Mount%27s%20Bay">Mount's Bay</a> and is in the northern part of the parish of <a href="Mullion%2C%20Cornwall">Mullion</a>; the <a href="Churchtown%2C%20Cornwall">churchtown</a> is to the south-east. On the north side of Poldhu Cove is the parish of <a href="Gunwalloe">Gunwalloe</a> and the village of <a href="Porthleven">Porthleven</a> is a further to the north.
Poldhu Point became the site of one of the main technological advances of the early twentieth century when, on 12 December 1901, a <a href="wireless">wireless signal</a> was sent by Thomas Barron in Poldhu to <a href="St.%20John%27s%2C%20Newfoundland%20and%20Labrador">St John's</a>, <a href="Newfoundland">Newfoundland</a>, and received by <a href="Guglielmo%20Marconi">Marconi</a>. The technology was a precursor to <a href="radio">radio</a>, <a href="television">television</a>, <a href="satellites">satellites</a> and the <a href="internet">internet</a>, with the <a href="Goonhilly%20Satellite%20Earth%20Station">earth station</a> at <a href="Goonhilly%20Downs">Goonhilly Downs</a> a nearby example.
In January 2016 Poldhu Cove was inundated with thousands of pink plastic bottles, brought onto the beach with successive tides. The <a href="National%20Trust%20for%20Places%20of%20Historic%20Interest%20or%20Natural%20Beauty">National Trust</a> said it believed a container had gone overboard from a ship, during the stormy weather.
Marconi's Poldhu Wireless Station.
The site is famous as the location of Poldhu Wireless Station, <a href="Guglielmo%20Marconi">Guglielmo Marconi</a>'s transmitter for the first transatlantic <a href="radio">radio</a> message on 12 December 1901. Marconi received the transmission on <a href="Signal%20Hill%2C%20Newfoundland%20and%20Labrador">Signal Hill</a>, <a href="St.%20John%27s%2C%20Newfoundland%20and%20Labrador">St. John's, Newfoundland</a>. The station was built partly on cliff top pastures that had been enclosed in 1871 and partly on medieval fields belonging to a nearby settlement, Angrouse. The fifty acre (200,000 m2) plot was bought in 1900 and building work ran from October 1900 to January 1901. During the work two <a href="Bronze%20Age%20Britain">Bronze Age</a> <a href="Tumulus%23United%20Kingdom">barrows</a> were flattened and a <a href="bronze">bronze</a> <a href="dagger">dagger</a> and <a href="urn">urn</a> were recovered.
To design the spark transmitter, the first high power radio transmitter in the world, Marconi hired Prof. <a href="John%20Ambrose%20Fleming">John Ambrose Fleming</a>, University College, London. The original twenty mast circular aerial was destroyed in a storm on 17 September 1901. Marconi hastily built a temporary aerial of 50 wires suspended in a fan shape from a cable between two 200 foot (61 m) masts. Fleming estimated the transmitter's radiated power was around 10–12 kW. The frequency used is not known precisely, as Marconi did not measure wavelength or frequency, but it was between 166 and 984 kHz, probably around 500 kHz. After the experiment the original mast layout was not rebuilt, it was replaced with a four mast design, 215 feet (66 m) high and forming a 200-foot (61 m) square.
Marconi later used the site for his <a href="shortwave">shortwave</a> experiments, with transmissions by <a href="Charles%20Samuel%20Franklin">Charles Samuel Franklin</a> to Marconi on the yacht in the <a href="Cape%20Verde%20Islands">Cape Verde Islands</a> in 1923 and in <a href="Beirut">Beirut</a> in 1924. The groundbreaking results of these experiments took the world by surprise and quickly resulted in his development of the <a href="Imperial%20Wireless%20Chain">Beam Wireless Service</a> for the British General Post Office. The service opened from the Bodmin Beam Station to Canada on 25 October 1926, from the to Australia on 8 April 1927, from the to South Africa on 5 July 1927, to India on 6 September 1927 and shortly afterwards to Argentina, Brazil and the United States.
The station closed in 1934 and was demolished in 1937. Six acres (24,000 m2) were given to the <a href="National%20Trust%20for%20Places%20of%20Historic%20Interest%20or%20Natural%20Beauty">National Trust</a> in 1937 with the rest of the site added in 1960. The site has a stone monument pillar, erected in November 1937 by the <a href="Marconi%20Company">Marconi Company</a>, and a number of concrete foundations and earth structures also remain. In 2001 the "Marconi Centre", a new museum / meeting building, was opened close to the site by the efforts of the Poldhu Amateur Radio Club, the National Trust, and <a href="Marconi%20plc">Marconi plc</a>.
The substantial building near the site, originally the Poldhu Hotel, built in 1899, is currently a <a href="Nursing%20home%20care%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">care home</a>. The visitors' book shows that Marconi stayed there in May and August 1901.
Marconi also built an earlier, smaller, experimental wireless station nearby at Housel Bay – <a href="The%20Lizard">The Lizard Wireless Station</a>.
In popular culture.
<a href="Sherlock%20Holmes">Sherlock Holmes</a> and <a href="Dr.%20Watson">Dr. Watson</a> are staying in a cottage above Poldhu beach in "<a href="The%20Adventure%20of%20the%20Devil%27s%20Foot">The Adventure of the Devil's Foot</a>", a short story by <a href="Arthur%20Conan%20Doyle">Arthur Conan Doyle</a>. In the first episode of "<a href="Miss%20Sherlock">Miss Sherlock</a>", "Poldhu" is the name of a brand of wireless <a href="medical%20telemetry">medical telemetry</a> devices in the form of a capsule that is swallowed by the user, which the murder exploits as triggers for liquid bombs that destroy the abdominal cavities of her victims.
